content.text: You follow Captain Beatty and your fellow firemen, Stoneman, and Black up the sidewalk.
They crash through the front door and grab at a woman, who made no move to escape.
You can still smell the strong scent of kerosene on your uniform.
She is standing, weaving from side to side, her eyes fixed upon a nothingness in the wall as if they had struck her a terrible blow upon the head.
Her tongue was moving in her mouth, and her eyes seemed to be trying to remember something, and then they remembered and her tongue moves again.

content.speaker: Old Woman
content.text: 'Play the man, Master Ridley; we shall this day light such a candle, by God's grace, in England, as I trust shall never be put out.'

content.speaker: Captain Beatty
content.text: Enough of that! Where are they?
Beatty slaps the woman's face, repeating the question.
The old woman's eyes came to a focus upon Beatty.

content.speaker: Old Woman
content.text: You know where they are, or you wouldn't be here
Beatty, Stoneman, and Black swing their silver hatchets at doors that were unlocked
A fountain of books fall upon you as you climb the sheer stairwell, but as you continue on
A book alights like a bird with its wings fluttering, landing in front of you
Time has fallen asleep in the afternoon sunshine-

content.speaker: Captain Beatty
content.text: Montag, up here!
Your coworkers are above you, hurling shovelfuls of magazines into the dusty air.
The magazines fall like slaughtered birds as the woman stands below, like a small girl, among the bodies.
With the chaos around you, you spot a book
Plunged under your arm, you hold it close.

content.speaker: Captain Beatty
content.text: Montag! Don't stand there, idiot!
The men danced and slipped and fell over the stockpile of books.
They coat each book with kerosene. You stagger after them in the fumes

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: Come on, woman!
They coat each book with kerosene. You stagger after them in the fumes
The woman knelt among the books, touching the drenched leather and cardboard while her eyes accused you.
The woman knelt among the books, touching the drenched leather and cardboard while her eyes accused you.

content.speaker: Old Woman
content.text: You can't ever have my books.

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: How oddly you say that.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: I'd—I'd have known it with my eyes shut. The smell of kerosene...

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: My wife always complains. You never wash it off completely. Kerosene is nothing but perfume to me.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Does it seem like that, really?

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: Of course. Why not?
She turns toward the houses. You find yourself walking beside her.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: I'm Clarisse McClellan. I'm seventeen and I'm crazy. Isn't this a nice night to walk?

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: I like to smell things and look at things, and sometimes stay up all night to watch the sun rise.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Do you ever read any of the books you burn?

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: That's against the law! Monday burn Millay, Wednesday Whitman, Friday Faulkner. That's the slogan.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Is it true that long ago firemen put fires out instead of starting them?

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Strange. I heard once that houses used to burn by accident and they needed firemen to stop the flames.

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: Why are you laughing?

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: I don't know. You laugh when I haven't been funny and you answer right off. You never stop to think.
You stop walking. You feel insulted, but you aren't sure why.

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: You are an odd one. Haven't you any respect?

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: I don't mean to be insulting. I just love to watch people too much, I guess.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Have you ever watched the jet cars racing? I think drivers don't know what grass is, because they never see it slowly.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: If you showed a driver a green blur, he'd say: 'That's grass!' A pink blur? 'A rose-garden!'

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: You think too many things.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Did you know billboards used to be only twenty feet long? Now they are two hundred feet because cars rush by so fast.

content.speaker: Montag
content.text: I didn't know that!
You laugh abruptly. Then you realize you don't know if she's right.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Bet I know something else. There's dew on the grass in the morning. And there's a man in the moon.
She stops at her front door. The porch light is the only one on in the whole street.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Good night! ...Wait.
She turns back to look at you with wonder and curiosity.

content.speaker: Clarisse
content.text: Are you happy?
But she is already gone—running in the moonlight. Her front door shuts gently.
Happy! Of all the nonsense. You stand alone in the cold night, staring at her door.
